Award.AwardTitle: REU: Hooked on Photonics, a collaborative REU program
Award.AbstractNarration: This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) at the National Science Foundation supports the renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Washington. Hooked on Photonics (HoP) is a 10-week REU program where undergraduates participate in research involving the development of photonic materials and devices with applications ranging from telecommunications to light-emitting devices to alternative energy. A unique aspect of HoP is that participants are located on the three campuses: University of Washington, Georgia Institute of Technology, and the University of Arizona. The advantages of a multi-campus REU program include leveraged recruiting and educational efforts, substantial program evaluation, and increased diversity of research activities. The HoP program includes research, content lectures, ethics training, career seminars, and scientific-presentation skill workshops. In addition to advancing photonics research, the goals of HoP are to (1) provide academically appropriate research experiences for lower-level undergraduate students who traditionally have had limited access to research (community college students and students from primarily undergraduate institutions), and (2) increase the number of women and underrepresented minorities who successfully complete Bachelor's and advanced degrees in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU program, Hooked on Photonics (HoP), was a unique multi-disciplinary, multi-university (involving University of Washington, University of Arizona, Georgia Tech) program which focused on providing research experiences to undergraduate students who traditionally had limited?access to research opportunities (i.e., community college students, and students from 4-year institutions with modest research programs). HoP also aimed to increase the number of women and underrepresented minorities who?successfully complete Bachelor’s and advanced degrees?in science and engineering.

The scientific focus paralleled those of an NSF-funded Science and Technology Center (STC) on Materials and Devices for Information?Technology Research (MDITR), which was centered at the University of Washington. MDITR research involved?the basic molecular and structural nature of non-traditional?(i.e. organic) information-technology materials; the synthesis of molecular systems with novel properties; and?the design and fabrication of useful, low-cost devices with?superior electronic, photonic, and opto-electronic?properties. HoP students participated in all aspects of this research.

Since the original HoP program began in 2005, over 200 undergraduate students have participated in research. During their time, every student has had to participate in poster symposiums such as the UW Summer Research Poster Symposium or at the SACNAS National Conference, and every student has had to write a report about their research, which have been compiled into printed books. This means the HoP program has resulted in >200 poster presentations and reports. Over the lifetime of HoP, an average of 45% of all participants was female; the participation of URM students has averaged 40% for the past eight years; additionally, the percentage of Community College students and those from PUIs has averaged 49% over the past four years.

The pre- and post-program surveys included a series of questions about anticipated impact of the HoP program on research and career interests, and graduate school attendance.  Highlights from the pre-program surveys indicated that the primary reasons for attending HoP were to gain research experience (62%) and to have a clearer understanding of what a career in scientific research entailed (48%). The post-program surveys indicated that the HoP students had a consensus on the greatest benefits of the program: Contributing to the development of research skills (50%); Improving task completion and work skills (20%); Networking (21%); Awareness of careers 32%.
